Hello
  Some words about CMAES... CMAES adapts the Gaussian distribution sh=
ape and size with a fully *deterministic* strategy, and thus, are not they =
are not parts of the genotype. This is different from Self-Adaptive Evoluti=
on Strategies (SAES), where Gaussian distribution shape and size is a part =
of the genotype. There are both theoretical analysis and experimental resul=
ts that show that the CMAES strategy is much faster to find the optimal Gau=
ssian distribution shape and size compared to a SAES strategy. This is well=
 explained here :

http://www.bionik.tu-berlin.de/user/niko/research_adapt.=
html

Regards,
Alexandre Devert 


--- En date de=A0: Mar 30.9.08, Kenneth =
Stanley <kstanley@...> a =E9crit=A0:
De: Kenneth Stanley <kstanle=
y@...>
Objet: [neat] Re: Article Documenting How Natural Selectio=
n is Not Good at Choosing At Least One of Its Own Parameters (Mutation Rate=
)
=C0: neat@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mardi 30 Septembre 2008, 5h20










 =
   
            Jeff, 



Do you remember if I was advocating natural selec=
tion choosing its own

parameters?  I don't recall the specific discussion.=
  In any case,

there was a time when I thought evolution could be good at =
things like

that, but my mind has been changing in recent years, so I appr=
eciate

what your paper is saying.  



I think what caused me to become a =
skeptic about these kinds of

meta-evolutionary approaches is speaking to p=
eople who advocate the

idea that evolution should "evolve its own encoding=
."  That idea is

connected to evolvability, which suggests that evolution =
can figure

out its own best parametrizations to become most effective at e=
volving

in a particular type of domain.  Working on encodings started to m=
ake

me think that the search space of encodings is simply too vast to

exp=
ect evolution itself to optimize the encoding.  It is basically a

vast met=
a-search, far vaster than the problem domain itself (which is

already vast=
 to begin with in ambitious cases), and the actual problem

domain would se=
em to locally obfuscate the landscape of

meta-parameters (just as your res=
ults show).  



Overall, I started to feel like human intuition is a bette=
r bet for

solving these meta-questions, or at least for addressing them

e=
ffectively.  Also, as we started to think about novelty search, I

started =
to realize that evolution often innovates *despite* selection

rather than =
because of it, which is even more complicating at the

meta-level.  That is=
, at a meta-level like encodings, if something

good came about, it might a=
ctually be because selection pressure was

low for a time.  In other words,=
 if selection pressure has been high,

the steps towards whatever optimal m=
eta-parameter was found would

never have been taken because the stepping s=
tones are meta-suboptimal.

 Just talking about this issue with all these "=
metas" reminds me why

it seems like wishful thinking to rely on evolution =
to determine

everything.  Luck and happenstance have to be accepted as fac=
tors.



In another sense, evolving meta-parameters optimally sounds

dange=
rously close to a free lunch.   If there is an algorithm that can

evolve t=
he right meta-parameters reliably, which in turn causes it to

always find =
the right solution, when would that algorithm fail?



The conclusion in my=
 view is to trust our instincts.  We (humans)

still have a role to play in=
 setting the parameters of our algorithms

, and in designing our encodings=
, by thinking about the problems they

are intended to solve.  We are proba=
bly not going to get away with

offloading all the responsibility on evolut=
ion itself, at least not if

you want to see it succeed in reasonable time.=




By the way, Jeff (here I go contradicting myself), there are

reportedl=
y evolutionary algorithms that seem to show that they benefit

from mutatin=
g mutation parameters.  Evolution Strategies come to mind.

 ES has done th=
is kind of thing for years.  CMA-ES now uses

statistical techniques to pre=
dict optimal mutation distributions. 

What do your results suggest about s=
uch approaches?  Are they just

working on "toy problems" or is there some =
explanation for why they

claim to derive benefit from evolving the paramet=
ers?



ken



--- In neat@yahoogroups. com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:=


>

> Hello all-

> 

> A while back we had a discussion about whether nat=
ural selection is

good at

> choosing its own parameters. Many people assu=
me that it would be

beneficial

> to evolve the parameters of a run (e.g. =
mutation rate, crossover rate,

> etc.). After having done some research in=
 the area I have concluded

that it

> does not work well.

> 

> When I ex=
pressed this view previously, some of you were very

skeptical. At

> that =
point, I promised to share a manuscript that investigates the issue

> once=
 it was published.

> 

> That manuscript finally came out yesterday in the=
 journal PLoS

Computational

> Biology. I am rather excited because they c=
hose it for the cover of the

> September issue. 

> 

> You can see it her=
e:

> www.ploscompbiol. org

> 

> Clune, et. al. =B3Natural Selection Fail=
s to Optimize Mutation Rates for

> Long-Term Adaptation on Rugged Fitness =
Landscapes.=B2

> 

> I am interested to see what you think. In particular,=
 I would like

to hear

> from those of you that were skeptical of my claim=
. Do you still feel

that

> evolution can manage itself in light of this w=
ork? Note: I recognize

that

> this paper only covers mutation rates. Howe=
ver, the mutation rate is

one of

> the most important parameters. Further=
more, I think similar issues will

> arise with other parameters that resul=
t in the perturbation of

genomes (e.g.

> crossover type and rate).

> 

>=
 

> PS. PLoS allows readers to rate articles. If you enjoyed the

article,=
 and

> have a second, please rate it highly. I would really appreciate it!=


> 

> PPS. If you are reading this email after October 25th or so, here i=
s a

> direct link to the article.

> 

> http://www.ploscomp biol.org/ doi=
/pcbi. 1000187

> 

> PPPS. I have another paper that found that evolving p=
arameters did

not work

> tremendously well. That paper covered more than =
just mutation rates.

You can

> check that out here:

> 

> https://www. m=
su.edu/~ jclune/publicati ons/CluneEtAl- meta-GAs. pdf

> 

> 

> Cheers,

=
> Jeff Clune
